overview.short: Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae is a Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, non-motile short rod classically associated with zoonotic exposure and erysipeloid infections.
overview.clinical_context: Most commonly causes localized erysipeloid after fish/meat/animal handling; can rarely cause bacteremia and endocarditis.

species_markers.notes: A strong discriminator among Gram-positive short rods when present.
Supports Erysipelothrix over motile short rods like Listeria.
Separates from catalase-positive Gram-positive rods in mixed differential.

common_confusions.reason: Similar morphology and blood agar growth; Listeria is motile and catalase positive.
Gram-positive rod morphology; biochemical overlap may occur in minimal panels.

when_to_question_identification: Catalase positivity argues against E. rhusiopathiae.
Motility suggests Listeria or other motile short rods.
Repeated H2S negativity should prompt re-check of media/conditions or alternative genus.

recommended_next_tests.test: H2S detection on TSI or iron-containing media
recommended_next_tests.reason: Key supportive marker; verify with appropriate incubation conditions.
Best practical confirmation to species level in routine labs.
